messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: The 𝑞-ary Gilbert–Varshamov bound can be improved for all but finitely many positive integers 𝑞

Paper Abstract: Abstract For any positive integer q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2 and any real number δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), let αq​(n,δ​n)subscript𝛼𝑞𝑛𝛿𝑛\alpha_{q}(n,\delta n) denote the maximum size of a subset of ℤqnsuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n} with minimum Hamming distance at least δ​n𝛿𝑛\delta n, where ℤq={0,1,…,q−1}subscriptℤ𝑞01…𝑞1\mathbb{Z}_{q}=\{0,1,\dotsc,q-1\} and n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}. The asymptotic rate function is defined by Rq​(δ)=lim supn→∞1n​logq⁡αq​(n,δ​n).subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛1𝑛subscript𝑞subscript𝛼𝑞𝑛𝛿𝑛R_{q}(\delta)=\limsup_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{n}\log_{q}\alpha_{q}(n,\delta n). The famous q𝑞q-ary asymptotic Gilbert–Varshamov bound, obtained in the 1950s, states that Rq​(δ)≥1−δ​logq⁡(q−1)−δ​logq⁡1δ−(1−δ)​logq⁡11−δ=defRGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿1𝛿subscript𝑞𝑞1𝛿subscript𝑞1𝛿1𝛿subscript𝑞11𝛿superscriptdefsubscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{q}(\delta)\geq 1-\delta\log_{q}(q-1)-\delta\log_{q}\frac{1}{\delta}-(1-\delta)\log_{q}\frac{1}{1-\delta}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathrm{def}}}{{=}}R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) for all positive integers q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2 and 0<δ<1−q−10𝛿1superscript𝑞10<\delta<1-q^{-1}. In the case that q𝑞q is an even power of a prime with q≥49𝑞49q\geq 49, the q𝑞q-ary Gilbert–Varshamov bound was firstly improved by using algebraic geometry codes in the works of Tsfasman, Vladut, and Zink and of Ihara in the 1980s. These algebraic geometry codes have been modified to improve the q𝑞q-ary Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) at a specific tangent point δ=δ0∈(0,1)𝛿subscript𝛿001\delta=\delta_{0}\in(0,1) of the curve RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) for each given integer q≥46𝑞46q\geq 46. However, the q𝑞q-ary Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) at δ=1/2𝛿12\delta=1/2, i.e., RGV​(1/2,q)subscript𝑅GV12𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(1/2,q), remains the largest known lower bound of Rq​(1/2)subscript𝑅𝑞12R_{q}(1/2) for infinitely many positive integers q𝑞q which is a generic prime and which is a generic non-prime-power integer. In this paper, we prove that the q𝑞q-ary Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) with δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1) can be improved for all but finitely many positive integers q𝑞q. Precisely, for any given number ε∈(0,12)𝜀012\varepsilon\in(0,\frac{1}{2}), if q𝑞q is large enough, then Rq​(δ)>RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{q}(\delta)>R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) for all δ∈[ε,1−ε]𝛿𝜀1𝜀\delta\in[\varepsilon,1-\varepsilon]. In particular, it is explicitly shown that Rq​(1/2)>RGV​(1/2,q)subscript𝑅𝑞12subscript𝑅GV12𝑞R_{q}(1/2)>R_{\mathrm{GV}}(1/2,q) for all integers q>exp⁡(29)𝑞29q>\exp(29). Furthermore, based on the q𝑞q-ary asymptotic Plotkin upper bound Rq​(δ)≤1−δ−δq−1subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿1𝛿𝛿𝑞1R_{q}(\delta)\leq 1-\delta-\frac{\delta}{q-1} for all positive integers q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2 and 0<δ<1−q−10𝛿1superscript𝑞10<\delta<1-q^{-1}, we can define the growth on the rate function Rq​(δ)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿R_{q}(\delta) for δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1) fixed and q𝑞q growing large as follows η(δ)=lim infq→∞1log⁡qlog[1−δ−Rq(δ)]−1.\eta(\delta)=\liminf_{q\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{\log q}\log[1-\delta-R_{q}(\delta)]^{-1}. The q𝑞q-ary Plotkin upper bound implies that the growth satisfies η​(δ)≤1𝜂𝛿1\eta(\delta)\leq 1, while the q𝑞q-ary Gilbert–Varshamov lower bound only provides the trivial bound η​(δ)≥0𝜂𝛿0\eta(\delta)\geq 0. In this paper, we show that the growth has actually a nontrivial lower bound as η​(δ)≥1/6𝜂𝛿16\eta(\delta)\geq 1/6 for δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1). These new lower bounds, which exceed the Gilbert–Varshamov bound, are achieved by using codes from geometry of numbers introduced by Lenstra in the 1980s.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Introduction to Analytic Number Theory",
        "The exceptional set for Goldbach’s problem in short intervals",
        "An improvement of the Gilbert–Varshamov bound over nonprime fields",
        "Explicit bounds for primes in arithmetic progressions.",
        "Global fields",
        "Number Theory Volume I: Tools and Diophantine Equations",
        "Set-coloring Ramsey numbers via codes",
        "Set-coloring Ramsey numbers and error-correcting codes near the zero-rate threshold",
        "Multiplicative Number Theory, 2nd Edition",
        "Excellent nonlinear codes from modular curves",
        "A simple derivation of the coding theorem and some applications",
        "A tower of Artin–Schreier extensions of function fields attaining the Drinfeld–Vladut bound",
        "A comparison of signalling alphabets",
        "On class field towers (in Russian)",
        "Codes on algebraic curves",
        "Algebra",
        "On modular curves over finite fields",
        "Congruence relations and Shimura curves",
        "Some remarks on the number of rational points of algebraic curves over finite fields",
        "How many primes decompose completely in an infinite unramified Galois extensions of a global field?",
        "On the difference between consecutive primes",
        "Codes from algebraic number fields",
        "A note on lower bounds",
        "The Theory of Error-Correcting Codes",
        "Finitude de tours et p𝑝p-tours T𝑇T-ramifiees moderees, S𝑆S-decomposees",
        "What is the maximum number of points on a curve over 𝔽2subscript𝔽2{\\mathbb{F}_{2}}?",
        "Tours de corps de classes et estimations de discriminants",
        "Topics in Multiplicative Number Theory",
        "Multiplicative Number Theory I. Classical Theory",
        "On a mean value theorem for the remainder term in the prime number theorem for short arithmetic progressions",
        "Algebraic Number Theory",
        "Rational Points on Curves over Finite Fields: Theory and Applications",
        "Binary codes with specified minimum distance",
        "On class field towers",
        "Explicit bounds for some functions of prime numbers",
        "Infinite class field towers of quadratic fields",
        "Algebraic curves over 𝔽2subscript𝔽2{\\mathbb{F}_{2}} with many rational points",
        "Sur le nombre des points rationnels d’une courbe algébrique sur un corps fini",
        "Nombres de points des courbes algébriques sur 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\\mathbb{F}_{q}",
        "Rational Points on Curves over Finite Fields",
        "Lower bounds to error probability for coding on discrete memoryless channels: Part I",
        "Lower bounds to error probability for coding on discrete memoryless channels: Part II",
        "A mean value theorem in geometry of numbers",
        "Algebraic Number Theory and Fermat’s Last Theorem, 3rd Edition",
        "Algebraic Function Fields and Codes, 2nd Edition",
        "Global class field theory",
        "Algebraic Geometric Codes: Basic Notions",
        "Algebraic Geometry Codes: Advanced Chapters",
        "Modular curves, Shimura curves, and codes better than the Varshamov–Gilbert bound",
        "Introduction to Coding Theory, 3rd Edition",
        "Estimate of the number of signals in error correcting codes",
        "Number of points of an algebraic curve",
        "On codes beyond the Gilbert bound (in Russian)"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in The 𝑞-ary Gilbert–Varshamov bound can be improved for all but finitely many positive integers 𝑞, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
